title-group.article-title: An analytic formulation for blind modal identification

contrib-group.aff: Stress Engineering Services, Inc., Houston, TX, USA

author-notes.corresp: SI McNeill, Stress Engineering Services, Inc., 13610 Westland East Boulevard, Houston, TX 77041, USA Email: scot.mcneill@stress.com

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2011 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: In this paper a complex-valued formulation of the modal superposition equation is provided and shown to be equivalent to the original, real-valued Blind Modal IDentification (BMID) problem. The complex-valued variant involves the analytic form of the physical and modal responses. The formulation is shown to be more concise and straightforward than the original. It is noted that complex-valued mode shapes can be obtained using a complex version of the two-step Joint Approximate Diagonalization (JAD) algorithm. Using this approach the modal response pairing step of the original BMID method is eliminated. Since the development of the original BMID method, several new, one-step JAD algorithms have been devised. Many of the algorithms can be extended to identify complex mixing matrices. A complex version of the one-step JAD method known as the Weighted Exhaustive Diagonalization with Gauss itErations algorithm is utilized to solve for the complex mode shapes and modal responses. By using this simplified formulation, the whitening step is eliminated, as well as the modal response pairing step, which is necessary in the original BMID algorithm.

Performance of the new Complex BMID (CBMID) algorithm is evaluated by application to synthesized data from a three-degrees-of-freedom system with complex modes, application to measured laboratory data on a structural frame and application to measured output-only data from the Heritage Court Tower building. It is seen that the CBMID method results in essentially the same estimates of modal responses, complex mode shapes, natural frequencies and modal damping compared to results from BMID. Furthermore, it is shown that modal parameters from BMID and CBMID are very consistent with those obtained from state-of-the-art methods, such as the Eigensystem Realization Algorithm and the covariance-driven Stochastic Subspace Identification method.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: Recently, a framework for Blind Modal IDentification (BMID) was developed to perform modal identification using Blind Source Separation (BSS) methods (McNeill, 2007; McNeill and Zimmerman, 2008, 2010). It was first shown that the Second Order Blind Identification (SOBI) algorithm is suitable for the modal identification task for systems with real-valued modes (diagonally damped systems). The SOBI algorithm finds special source components in measured physical response data, consisting of linear mixtures of the sources. SOBI applies Joint Approximate Diagonalization (JAD) on a set of data covariance matrices to solve for the unknown sources and mixing matrix. When applied to vibration data, the system mode shapes were shown to correspond to the mixing matrix and the modal responses were shown to correspond to the source components.

The objective of BMID is to extend SOBI to systems with complex-valued modes (nondiagonally damped systems), allowing for estimation of complex-valued mode shapes, natural frequencies and modal damping. The version of the JAD algorithm used in the original work (McNeill and Zimmerman, 2008) involved two steps: a whitening step, using a real-valued whitening matrix; and a data rotation, using a real-valued, orthogonal (rotation) matrix. The JAD algorithm used solved for the rotation matrix using a Jacobi routine, described by Belouchrani et al. (1997). The real-valued, nonunitary mixing matrix was then constructed as the product of the inverse whitening matrix and the rotation matrix.

Since the real-valued, two-step JAD algorithm used was not capable of identifying a complex-valued mixing matrix, the complex-valued modal superposition equations were converted to a real-valued system of twice the size to solve for the real and imaginary parts of the complex modes using the available SOBI algorithm. However, versions of two-step JAD are available for complex-valued data, which estimate complex-valued mixing and demixing matrices, allowing for a complex-valued formulation for BMID. Furthermore, several new algorithms were devised to solve for a mixing matrix that is generally nonunitary, some of which have been extended to the complex-valued case. This allows omission of the whitening step.

A complex-valued formulation of the modal superposition equation is provided in this work, and shown to be equivalent to the original, real-valued BMID problem. An appropriate one-step JAD algorithm for complex-valued data is suggested. The remainder of this document is organized as follows. The complex-valued formulation for BMID is provided in Section 2. The formulation is shown to be equivalent to the original BMID formulation and its merits are discussed. An appropriate JAD algorithm is suggested. Following this, the method is demonstrated using a simple numerical example in Section 3, measured laboratory data from a structural frame in Section 4, and measured output-only data from the Heritage Court Tower (HCT) building in Section 5. Concluding remarks are provided in Section 6.

sec.title: 2. Complex-valued formulation for Blind Modal Identification
sec.p: The modal superposition principal states that the physical response, xr(t)∈Rn, of a vibrating system is composed of the superposition of the modal responses, p(t)∈C2m, by (1)xr(t)=Ψp(t).

Here the matrix of complex mode shapes is denoted as Ψ∈Cn×2m and the subscript r is used to indicate that the physical response is real-valued. Since this is the case, the mode shapes and modal responses must appear in complex conjugate pairs. Equation (1) becomes (2)xr(t)=[Φ,Φ*][q(t)q*(t)]=2Re{Φq(t)}, where Φ∈Cn×m, q(t)∈Cm and (•)* indicates complex conjugation. It is known that the modal responses take the form of an analytic signal q~(t)=qr(t)+iq∧r(t), where qr(t) is the real part of the modal responses, q∧r(t) is the Hilbert transform of qr(t) and i is the imaginary unit. Information on the Hilbert transform may be found in the book by Feldman (2011), as well as many other references. Using this identity and absorbing the factor of two into the modal matrix, we have (3)xr(t)=Re{[Φr+iΦi](qr(t)+iq∧r(t))}.

Here the real and imaginary parts of the complex mode matrix are written explicitly. Now allow the physical responses to be complex by removing the real-value operator from the right-hand side of Equation (3). It follows that the imaginary part of the physical response is the Hilbert transform of the real part, because the physical response is a linear combination of the analytic modal responses. Therefore, the physical responses admit an analytic representation, x~(t)=xr(t)+ix∧r(t). Note that the real part represents the true physical responses. This results in the complex-valued mode superposition equation: (4)x~(t)=Φq~(t),xr(t)+ix∧r(t)=[Φr+iΦi](qr(t)+iq∧r(t)).
The real and imaginary parts of the modal responses can be separated to yield (5)xr(t)+ix∧r(t)=[Φr+iΦi,-Φi+iΦr][qr(t)q∧r(t)].
Similarly, the real and imaginary part of the physical responses can be separated to arrive at (6)[xr(t)x∧r(t)]=[Φr,-ΦiΦi, Φr][qr(t)q∧r(t)].

Equation (6) is of the form used by McNeill and Zimmerman (2008). In the reference, the Hilbert transform pairs of the measured physical response data, x∧r(t), were appended to the vector of measured data, xr(t), and the original SOBI algorithm was applied to estimate the real-valued modal matrix and modal responses components on the right-hand side of Equation (6). Because there is no particular order to the estimated modal responses, a pairing routine was needed to match the Hilbert transform pairs of the estimated modal response components.

Clearly Equation (6) is equivalent to Equation (4), from which it was derived. When BMID was developed, the formulation in Equation (6) was chosen along with a real-valued, two-step version of the JAD algorithm. However, the complex-valued formulation in Equation (4) can be solved using a complex-valued version of two-step JAD. A complex, two-step version of JAD may be found at online at the Telecom ParisTech Personal Websites (2011). This results in elimination of the modal response pairing routine. The complex, two-step JAD algorithm was implemented in the BMID version found in the Matlab® toolbox (Matlab Central File Exchange, 2011).

Although the complex, two-step JAD algorithm works quite well, the whitening step can be avoided by using one of the newly developed one-step versions of JAD. These algorithms can estimate nonunitary, complex-valued mixing matrices and complex-valued source components in a single step (no whitening). A version of the high-performance Weighted Exhaustive Diagonalization with Gauss itErations (WEDGE) algorithm (Tichavsky et al., 2008; Tichavsky and Yeredor, 2009) is suggested to solve for the complex mode shapes and modal responses. The algorithm has been coded in Matlab®, and is available for research use via the Personal pages of Petr Tichavsky (2011). By using this simplified formulation, the whitening step is eliminated, as well as a modal response pairing step that is necessary in the original BMID algorithm. The SOBI algorithm was modified to use the complex-valued WEDGE routine. This was then incorporated into the BMID framework and termed Complex BMID (CBMID).

sec.title: 3. Application to synthesized data
sec.p: In order to illustrate that the application of the CBMID formulation yields the same results as the original, the three-degrees-of-freedom system example (with nondiagonal damping) found in the work of McNeill and Zimmerman (2008) is repeated. The system mass, damping and stiffness matrices are, respectively M=[3 0 00 2 00 0 1], C=[0.18560.2290-0.97020.22900.0308-0.0297-0.9702-.02970.1241],K=[4 -2 0-2 4 -20 -2 10].

Free-decay from initial conditions was simulated. Displacement responses and their Fast Fourier Transform (FFT) are shown in Figure 1. The CBMID algorithm was applied to the analytic data. The estimated modal responses are shown in Figure 2 and the estimated complex mode shapes ΨCBMID, are given, along with the values obtained using the original BMID, ΨBMID, below: ΨCBMID=[1.0000-0.6778+0.0357i0.0090+0.1246i0.9448-0.0230i1.0000-0.1220-0.0154i0.2016-0.0954i0.2703+0.1330i1.0000],ΨBMID=[1.0000-0.6778+0.0354i0.0099+0.1282i0.9452-0.0210i1.0000-0.1231-0.0178i0.2019-0.0951i0.2702+0.1331i1.0000]. Figure 1.
Response of three-degrees-of-freedom system to initial conditions (complex modes). Figure 2.
Estimated modal responses using Complex Blind Modal Identification (complex modes).

Estimated modal responses using BMID are indistinguishable from those of CBMID, so they are not shown in Figure 2. It can be seen that the CBMID formulation yields essentially the same results as the original BMID algorithm. The small differences are attributed to differences in the respective numerical JAD routines employed by each of the methods. Natural frequency and damping resulting from application of BMID and CBMID are presented in Table 1, along with the analytical values. It can be seen that the modal parameters are identical for the two algorithms and are extremely close to analytical values. Table 1.
Estimated natural frequency and damping (complex modes)
Analytical BMID CBMID
Mode # Frequency [Hz] Damping [% critical] Frequency [Hz] Damping [% critical] Frequency [Hz] Damping [% critical]
1 0.136 3.02 0.136 3.02 0.136 3.02
2 0.247 1.37 0.247 1.36 0.247 1.36
3 0.500 1.71 0.500 1.69 0.500 1.69
BMID: Blind Modal Identification, CBMID: Complex Blind Modal Identification

Both the BMID and CBMID algorithms are robust to uncorrelated noise because covariance matrices of time-shifted data are used. Further discussion of the robustness to noise for BMID can be found in McNeill (2007). However, the performance of two-step JAD algorithms is limited in the presence of noise, due to the additional whitening phase, as discussed by Cardoso (1994). One-step JAD algorithms do not exhibit this limitation. Gaussian-random, uncorrelated noise was added to the data and the simulation was repeated. The noise level was set such that the maximum value of the noise was 10% of the maxim value of the noise-free data. The estimated modal responses using CBMID are shown in Figure 3. Obviously the algorithm has no difficulty estimating the modal responses in the presence of significant additive noise. In fact if n < m, noise will be estimated as source components, reducing the noise level in the estimated modal responses. The original BMID algorithm yields essentially the same results for this noise level. A comprehensive investigation of the relative noise performance for the two algorithms is beyond the scope of this paper. Figure 3.
Estimated modal responses using Complex Blind Modal Identification (complex modes with noise).

sec.title: 4. Application to measured laboratory data from a structural frame
sec.p:
In order to investigate the performance of CBMID on measured laboratory data, CBMID is applied to the structural frame example of McNeill and Zimmerman (2008). The experimental structure is a welded rectangular steel frame with bolted cross members, as seen in Figure 4. Dynamic test data were recorded using 28 sensors with impact excitation. Frequency content from 110 to 875 Hz was analyzed. To get an idea of the modal content of the data, acceleration Power Spectral Density (PSD) functions were computed. Then the envelope was computed over all channels for each frequency. This simple mode indicator function is shown in Figure 5. Results from the bandwidth 100–370 Hz are focused on here, due to the low signal-to-noise ratio. More details on the experimental setup can be found in McNeill and Zimmerman (2008). Figure 4.
Structural frame. Figure 5.
Acceleration Power Spectral Density (PSD) envelope (structural frame).

Three methods were used to extract the modal parameters from the bandpass-filtered data: BMID, CBMID and the Eigensystem Realization Algorithm (ERA). The ERA is a parametric method that identifies a state-space system from impulse response or free-decay data (Juang and Pappa, 1985).

Results of the parameter extraction are shown in Table 2. The table contains columns for mode shape comparison based on the Modal Assurance Criterion (MAC). The MAC value between two mode shapes φ1 and φ2 is given by (7)MAC(φ1,φ2)=(φ1Hφ2)2‖φ1‖2‖φ2‖2. Table 2.
Identified modal parameters for the structural frame (100–370 Hz)
ERA BMID CBMID
Mode # Freq. (Hz) Damp (%) Mode # Freq. (Hz) Damp (%) MAC 1-2 Mode # Freq. (Hz) Damp (%) MAC 1-3 MAC 2-3
1 121.71 1.71 1 121.45 1.75 0.87 1 121.48 1.45 0.91 0.96
2 154.75 1.55 2 154.75 1.51 1.00 2 154.79 1.54 1.00 1.00
3 195.47 1.22 3 195.47 1.22 1.00 3 195.48 1.21 1.00 1.00
4 221.58 0.68 4 221.57 0.64 1.00 4 221.55 0.64 1.00 1.00
5 226.64 0.34 5 226.61 0.33 1.00 5 226.61 0.34 1.00 1.00
6 245.64 1.42 6 245.64 1.46 1.00 6 245.57 1.47 1.00 1.00
7 309.36 0.96 7 309.40 0.96 1.00 7 309.39 0.97 1.00 1.00
8 341.22 0.75 8 341.35 0.76 1.00 8 341.35 0.76 1.00 1.00
ERA: Eigensystem Realization Algorithm, BMID: Blind Modal Identification, CBMID: Complex Blind Modal Identification

Here, (•)H denotes the Hermetian (complex conjugate) transpose. A value near 1 indicates a good correlation. A value near 0 indicates poor correlation. In the MAC columns, extraction 1 corresponds to ERA, 2 corresponds to BMID and 3 corresponds to CBMID. For example, MAC 1-2 indicated that the MAC is between the ERA and BMID modes. It can be seen that natural frequency, modal damping and mode shape estimates are very consistent between the three methods.

Even numbered modal responses from the CBMID method are plotted in Figure 6. Notice that the estimated modal responses exhibit a nice monotone exponential decay and a single peak in the spectrum. It is then concluded that the quality of the modal responses estimated with CBMID is quite good. Figure 6.
Estimated modal responses using Complex Blind Modal Identification (structural frame).

sec.title: 5. Application to measured output-only data from the Heritage Court Tower building
sec.p:
The structure analyzed in this section is the HCT building. The description of the building, provided by Ventura et al. (2001), is summarized here. The HCT is located in downtown Vancouver, British Columbia, Canada. It is a 15-story reinforced concrete shear core building. The building is essentially rectangular in shape with only small projections and setbacks. The building tower is short and stout, having a height to width aspect ratio of approximately 1.7 in the east–west direction and 1.3 in the north–south direction. An overview of the building is presented in Figure 7. Typical floor dimensions of the upper floors are about 25 meters by 31 meters, while the dimensions of the lower three levels are about 36 meters by 30 meters. The footprint of the building below ground level is about 42 meters by 36 meters. The height of the first story is 4.7 meters, while most of the other levels have heights of 2.7 meters. Elevator and stairs corridors are concentrated at the center core of the building and form the main lateral resisting elements against potential wind and seismic lateral and torsional forces. The tower structure sits on top of four levels of reinforced concrete underground parking. A parking structure extends approximately 14 meters beyond the tower in the south direction, forming an L-shape with the tower. The parking structure and first floors of the tower are fairly flush on the remaining three sides. Because the building sits to the north side of the underground parking structure, coupling of the torsional and lateral modes of vibration was expected primarily in the east–west direction. Figure 7.
Photograph of the Heritage Court Tower building.

Ambient response data were obtained from the website (ARTeMIS, 2007). Four sets of ambient response data were collected with eight accelerometers. Six of the accelerometers were roving transducers that changed location for each data set. Two reference accelerometers remained in a fixed location. This enables the mode shapes computed from the four data sets to be combined into one modal matrix. The data sets contained around 325 seconds of data, sampled at 40 Hz.

The third data set was analyzed using BMID and CBMID, as well as the parametric method, known as covariance-driven Stochastic Subspace Identification (SSI). Covariance-driven SSI is essentially an application of the ERA on cross-correlation functions instead of impulse response functions. More details of the SSI algorithm can be found in Peeters (2000). Channels 2, 4, 7 and 8 were chosen as reference channels for SSI. The BMID and CBMID methods were applied on the ambient responses directly. An example time history is given in Figure 8 and the first two Complex Mode Indicator Functions (CMIFs) are shown in Figure 9. From the CMIF plot, it can be seen that the first three modes are closely spaced. In fact the first two modes (∼1.25 Hz) are so closely spaced that they are nearly the same frequency. As a result, the first CMIF does not exhibit two distinct peaks. However, the presence of the second mode at ∼1.25 Hz is indicated by the peak in the second CMIF. There is a sharp peak in the first CMIF around 8.7 Hz. This is most likely harmonic noise due to a mechanical device, such as a motor, fan or pump. Also notice that, above 10 Hz, there are no distinct peaks visible. This data set presents a challenge to the BMID method due to the small number of sensors, the presence of closely spaced modes and the presence of harmonic noise. Figure 8.
Example time series response (Heritage Court Tower building). Figure 9.
First two Complex Mode Indicator Functions (CMIFs) (Heritage Court Tower building).

For the SSI method, the data set was bandpass filtered into three bands (0.0–7.2, 6.8–10.2 and 10.2–20.0 Hz). The SSI method was performed with several different Toeplitz matrix sizes, resulting in several realizations. Consistency diagrams were formed for each filter band, and the best realization was chosen. The consistency diagrams can be found in McNeill and Zimmerman (2010). For the BMID method, the data set was bandpass filtered into four bands (0.0–3.0, 2.4–7.0, 7.0–8.6 and 8.8–20.0 Hz). It was desirable to use this choice of filter bands due to the closely spaced modes near 1.5 Hz, harmonic noise around 8.7 Hz and the small number of accelerometers.

Modal parameters from each filter band were combined and are presented in Table 3. Results between the three methods compare well in general. All methods identified the same modes. Comparing the results from BMID and CBMID, it can be seen that the modal parameters (frequencies, damping ratios and mode shapes) are essentially the same, exhibiting only slight numerical differences. In addition, modal parameters from BMID and CBMID compare extremely will to those obtained using SSI. Only mode 13 has a MAC value that falls below 0.9. Natural frequency and damping values are remarkably consistent. Table 3.
Identified modal parameters for the Heritage Court Tower building
SSI BMID CBMID
Mode # Freq. (Hz) Damp (%) Mode # Freq. (Hz) Damp (%) MAC 1-2 Mode # Freq. (Hz) Damp (%) MAC 1-3 MAC 2-3
1 1.23 1.25 1 1.23 1.22 1.00 1 1.23 1.22 1.00 1.00
2 1.29 1.08 2 1.28 1.09 1.00 2 1.28 1.09 1.00 1.00
3 1.45 0.86 3 1.45 0.70 1.00 3 1.45 0.70 1.00 1.00
4 3.86 1.29 4 3.87 1.40 1.00 4 3.87 1.40 1.00 1.00
5 4.26 1.74 5 4.26 1.45 1.00 5 4.26 1.45 1.00 1.00
6 5.33 2.40 6 5.33 2.70 1.00 6 5.33 2.70 1.00 1.00
7 6.38 1.69 7 6.36 1.60 0.99 7 6.36 1.56 1.00 1.00
8 7.49 2.84 8 7.50 1.89 0.95 8 7.53 2.07 0.92 0.98
9 7.54 2.17 9 7.55 1.97 0.98 9 7.55 2.20 0.98 0.98
10 7.93 1.44 10 7.92 1.61 0.95 10 7.93 1.58 0.93 0.99
11 8.21 1.58 11 8.28 2.00 0.95 11 8.28 2.06 0.96 1.00
12 9.31 1.63 12 9.29 1.85 1.00 12 9.29 1.84 1.00 1.00
13 11.11 4.48 13 11.31 5.40 0.88 13 11.29 5.52 0.89 1.00
14 12.51 1.48 14 12.03 4.29 0.93 14 12.04 4.23 0.92 1.00
15 15.32 5.15 15 15.27 5.01 0.95 15 15.27 5.14 0.97 0.99
16 16.23 3.84 16 16.08 3.39 0.92 16 16.12 3.50 0.92 1.00
SSI: Stochastic Subspace Identification, BMID: Blind Modal Identification, CBMID: Complex Blind Modal Identification

Selected modal response estimates from the CBMID method are shown in Figure 10. The left-hand column of subplots shows the first 35 seconds of the modal response time history. The middle column of subplots shows the autocorrelation function of each modal response. Note that the time scale is zoomed in on the lower two plots. The right-hand column of subplots shows the FFT of the autocorrelation function, which is a scaled acceleration spectral density plot of the modal response. The modal response autocorrelation functions exhibit clean, monotone decay and the spectral peaks are seen to be quite well separated. Figure 10.
Estimated modal responses using Complex Blind Modal Identification (Heritage Court Tower building).

sec.title: 6. Summary and conclusions
sec.p: A complex-valued modal superposition formulation was provided, utilizing the analytic signal form of the data. The real-valued, augmented formulation used for the original BMID was derived from this equation, by separating the real and imaginary parts, thus showing the equivalence of the two formulations. A complex-valued implementation of the one-step JAD routine, WEDGE, was utilized to estimate the complex-valued mode shapes and modal responses. These techniques were implemented into the BMID framework to form CBMID. The equivalence of BMID and CBMID was demonstrated on a simple numerical example problem, measured laboratory data from a structural frame, and output-only measured data from the HCT building. Small differences in the results between BMID and CBMID are attributed to differences in the numerical algorithms used for JAD. Modal parameters obtained from BMID and CBMID were shown to be very consistent with those obtained from state-of-the-art methods, such as the ERA and SSI. The CBMID method has some advantages over BMID: the formulation is more concise, the whitening step is omitted and there is no longer a need for the pairing routine.

ack.title: Acknowledgement
ack.p: The author wishes to express his gratitude to Petr Tichavsky for making the complex-valued WEDGE routine available for research purposes.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial or not-for-profit sectors.
